questions.query: The wing structure of a modern transport aeroplane is of the following type...
The main reason the pilot seat is made adjustable is that the pilot can...

options.text: put his/her eyes in the eye reference position.
look outside during taxiing, take-off and landing but look inside during cruise flight.

questions.query: In a damage tolerant construction...

options.text: redundancy makes sure the construction does not fail.
fatigue cracks are acceptable within predetermined criteria.

questions.query:
Regarding a large jet transport aeroplane, what would be the advantage of wing mounted engines over fuselage mounted engines?

  1. reduced wing-root loading;
  2. less susceptible to wing flutter;
  3. no need for booster pumps.

 

Note:

In the future there will be no EASA LO for this question!

During a high, positive wing load the...

  1. upper wing skin experiences a compression load;
  2. lower wing skin experiences a tension load.

 

Note:

There is no EASA LO for this question!

If a straight wing is bent downward, the lateral wing loads in the lower skin will be...

 

Note:

In the future there will be no EASA LO for this question!

If a straight wing is bent upward, the lateral wing loads in the lower skin will be...

 

Note:

In the future there will be no EASA LO for this question!

A negative tail load will cause in the lower fuselage skin a...

 

Note:

In the future there will be no EASA LO for this question!

Which statement regarding fatigue is true?

  1. Fatigue depends on number of load cycles;
  2. Fatigue occurs when the load exceeds the elastic limit.
The Dutch word for 'fatigue' is...
Corrosion is...
Aircraft maintenance with a fixed Time Between Overhaul (TBO) is typically...
Replacing a wheel after exceeding its speed rating, is a form of...

Which statement about aircraft maintenance is correct?

  1. Hard-time maintenance is a method to remove a part after a specified number of flight cycles or hours;
  2. On-condition maintenance is a method to determine a part's performance which may lead to a preventive removal.
A cantilever wing construction...

options.text: makes use of a semi-monocoque construction instead of a truss web.

questions.query: When looking at the structural strength, the most ideal cross-section for a pressurised fuselage is...
Compared to aluminium reinforced structures, carbon-fibre reinforced structures are used to increase the...
Composite material...

options.text: does in principle not suffer from fatigue.
is a monocoque construction that requires stringers and frames.
consist of a sandwich of two metal sheets with in between a honeycomb filler.

questions.query: A construction consisting of two skin panels with in between a filler material is called a...
Ribs transfer loads from the...
The wing torsion box is the...

options.text: part of the wing consisting of front and rear spars including the reinforced skin in between.

questions.query: The wing structure of a modern transport aeroplane is of the following type:
A cantilever-type wing construction...

options.text: employs spars that are interconnected in the fuselage.
is made as a girder framework (truss web).
consists of two- or three wings on top of each other.
makes use of braces to support the wing load.

questions.query: The main function of the vertical tailplane is to...
The empennage of a modern jet transport aeroplane is made as a(n)...

What may be carried in the fuselage?

  1. passengers;
  2. cargo;
  3. fuel.

Which statement regarding cockpit windows is correct?

  1. If the windshield heating system has a failure, on some aeroplanes an additional speed limitation comes into force with regard to protection for bird impact;
  2. Side windows have a pneumatic de-icing system.

A fuselage frame:

  1. gives shape to the fuselage cross-section;
  2. holds the windows, doors and hatches;
  3. is a reinforcement to attach engines, landing gear and wings;
  4. transfers loads from the longerons to the skin.

The answer that contains most correct statements is...
A direct vision window is a...

options.text: cockpit window that can be opened to allow the flight crew to check their flight path visually in case of an obstructed windshield.
windshield equipped with wipers and heating elements to ensure a clear view during precipitation conditions.
small window in the flight- or passenger compartment door to allow the flight crew to check the area in front of the door.
small window that allows the flight crew to check the landing gear visually in case of a failure of the normal indicating system.

questions.query: The tail bumper or tail skid must prevent...

options.text: damage to the horizontal and vertical stabiliser.

questions.query: The structural limitation MRM is the maximum...

Which statement concerning the following maximum masses is correct?

 

Note:

MRM = Maximum Ramp Mass

MTOM = Maximum Take-Off Mass

MZFM = Maximum Zero Fuel Mass

MLM = Maximum Landing Mass
Airframe life is limited by...
Hydrostatic pressure accounts for...

options.text: static air pressure on top of the hydraulic reservoir.

questions.query: Which statement on hydraulic pressure is correct?

options.text: During taxiing the hydraulic pressure in the actuator of the landing gear brake system is higher than the hydraulic pressure in the actuator of the horizontal stabiliser of a T-tail aircraft.
Because the hydraulic pressure depends on the height and the gravity, the pressure at cruise flight level is lower than the pressure at sea level.
Synthetic fluids and mineral fluids have more or less the same density and viscosity and can be pressurised to the same value.
Hydraulic systems of aircraft are pressurised by dynamic pressure; high speed aircraft therefore use higher system pressures than low speed aircraft.

questions.query: The hydraulic system pressure in large transport aeroplanes is...

Given:

An aircraft has a hydraulic system with a normal operating pressure of 3000 psi.

 

When during a pre-flight inspection the hydraulic system pressure is 0 psi, the accumulator gas pressure is about...

The ram air turbine...

 

Note: When the word 'automatically' is used, no pilot action will be required!

options.text: is designed to operate satisfactory until touchdown.
is located in the ram-air inlet of the airconditioning system.
can supply electric-, pneumatic- and/or hydraulic power.

questions.query: Hydraulic fluid is fed to the hydraulic pump under some pressure to prevent...
The ram-air turbine or just RAT is driven by the...
In large aircraft hydraulic systems, hydraulic fluid is supplied to the main pumps by...
The hydraulic system pressure of a large transport aircraft is regulated by the...

options.text: system accumulator whose piston can move up/down by gas pressure to maintain the system pressure.
pressure relief valve parallel to the pump relieving any excessive pressure to the pump inlet.
engine pump itself through a movable swash-plate controlled by a springloaded piston.
reservoir air pressure regulator using regulated bleed-air.

questions.query: The gas pressure in the accumulator of the hydraulic system is...

options.text: always one third (1/3) of the hydraulic system pressure.
depending on the air pressure on top of the hydraulic reservoir.

questions.query: To prevent the loss of the flight control system during a hydraulic leak...

options.text: the hydraulic system is equiped with a power transfer unit.
as an alternative to hydraulic actuators, the primary flight control surfaces are also connected to electric- and pneumatic actuators.
multiple, independent hydraulic systems may pressurise the actuators of the primary flight control surfaces.
the hydraulic system can be pressurised by air through the reservoir.

questions.query: One of the functions of a hydraulic accumulator is to...

options.text: compensate for fluid loss in case of a leak.

questions.query: In which of the following situations is an electric-driven hydraulic pump most probably needed?

options.text: When the flight controls are to be checked during taxi-out.
In case of loss of all hydraulic fluid from the system concerned.
In case of a combined slat/flap selection during approach.

questions.query:
When the camplate (swashplate or yoke) of a variable-displacement, constant-pressure hydraulic pump is at the upright position, the...

  1. pump stops rotation;
  2. system pressure is maintained;
  3. pump cooling and lubrication ceases.
When during a walk-around inspection, the gas pressure in a hydraulic accumulator equals the ambient pressure, this must be considered as...

options.text: normal: when the hydraulic pumps are off, the gas pressure reduces to ambient.
not normal: the hydraulic system has a fluid leak.
not normal: the accumulator has a gas leak.
normal: when the engines are off there is no bleed-air pressure.

questions.query:
During a walk-around inspection, the pilot finds the accumulator fluid pressure to be one third of the normal working pressure.

This is normal because the...

options.text: hydraulic pumps are not in operation and the accumulator may be used to supply the (parking) brakes.
there is no electricity to keep the indicator needle at the correct value.
accumulator pressure is always one third of the normal hydraulic system pressure.

questions.query: When both engines of a twin-engined jet transport aircraft fail, and there is no APU, hydraulic pressure for the flight control system can be restored by a(n)...

options.text: three-phase electric motor driving a hydraulic pump.

questions.query: Why is the hydraulically operated, horizontal stabiliser normally operated by a rotary actuator, and not by a linear actuator?

options.text: Linear piston actuators move to an undetermined position after a hydraulic failure.

questions.query: The anti-retraction mechanism of the landing gear lever consists of...

options.text: a spring that pushes two levers in an overcentred position.
a solenoid-operated pin that prevents movement of the landing gear lever.
a drag stay and a side strut that prevents a gear collapse.
hydraulic actuator that operates the torque links of the oleo-pneumatic strut.

questions.query:
Regarding the landing-gear alerting-system, as long as the gear is...

  1. up and locked, a blue gear alert is given;
  2. down and locked, a green alert is given.

Ground inspection of the main landing gear reveals that one leg is more compressed than the other.

The cause may be...

 

Note: The centre of gravity is located exactly on the longitudinal axis.

options.text: leakage of nitrogen in the most compressed leg.
too little oil in the least compressed leg.
the wheel of the least compressed leg is sitting in a hole.

questions.query: The main landing gear of a straight winged aircraft with a tricycle landing gear is located...

options.text: at the position of the center main gear.

questions.query: During touch-down, the landing shock is absorbed through...

options.text: a piston in a cylinder filled with a liquid and a gas.

questions.query: Ground steering in small aeroplanes like Cessna's, Piper's and Beechcraft's is normally achieved through the...

options.text: rudder pedals backed-up by the brake pedals.

questions.query: Nosewheel steering is performed through the...

options.text: a dedicated trim wheel on the pedestal.

questions.query: The power for nosewheel steering in large transport aeroplanes comes from...
One of the inputs to the computer of the automatic braking system is...
Which statement regarding the autobrake system (ABS) is correct?

options.text: An armed ABS activates as soon as the ground spoilers extend.
The braking distance on a dry runway only depends on the groundspeed at touchdown, and not on the aeroplane weight or the use of the thrust reverser.
An ABS deactivates automatically when the wheelspeed is low (<15 kt).
When the ABS is not armed before take-off, the take-off warning system will give an alert when advancing the throttle.

questions.query: After landing the autobrake system stops operation...

What are - amongst others - the functions of the skid control system...

  1. to allow differential braking;
  2. to stop wheel rotation during gear retraction;
  3. to prevents touchdown with brakes on;
  4. to reduce the landing distance.
The purpose of the fusible plug that is installed in some aircraft wheels is to...

options.text: prevent the brake pads from sticking to the brake disk at a too high temperature.
protect a tire against explosion at a too high temperature.
prevent spillage of brake fluid when hydraulic lines are damaged.

questions.query: The fusible plugs in the wheels protect against...

options.text: overpressure due to high temperatures during hard braking.
high pressures due to a high taxi speed.
high pressures due to hard- or overweight landings.

questions.query: Which statement regarding the gust lock is correct?

options.text: The gust lock is necessary on fully powered flight controls.
During take-off, the gust lock must be on.
A gust lock on the elevator decreases the load factor due to a gust.
A gust lock can be found on manually operated elevators and ailerons.

questions.query: Which of the following is a primary flight control surface?
What is the consequence of a jammed stabiliser?

options.text: The aircraft may lose pitch control when the speed is changed.
Passengers must be moved for pitch trim control.
Fuel must be cross-fed for pitch trim control.
The elevator can no longer be moved.

questions.query: The primary flight control surfaces of a large transport aeroplane, are primarily operated through...
What measure has been taken to prevent excessive stress on the vertical stabiliser in case of large rudder inputs?

options.text: Reduction of the rudder deflection with increasing speed.
Installation of an extra spar in the vertical stabiliser.
Attachment of the vertical stabiliser to the fuselage with six bolts.
Installation of a dorsal fin just in front of the vertical stabiliser.

questions.query: The primary flight controls are the...

options.text: ground steering systems such as the nosewheel steering system, the differential braking system and the ground spoilers.
trim tabs allowing flight control in case the normal conventional flight controls fail.

questions.query: In a fully manual flight control system...

options.text: control tabs are installed to increase the control forces exerted by the pilot.
all control forces are exerted by the pilot.
the flight control surfaces deflect over the same angle as their input.

questions.query: Adverse yaw is counteracted with help of...

options.text: a rudder deflection in the direction of the low wing.

questions.query: A conventional, and fully-powered flight control system requires no...
Which statement on aileron control is true?

options.text: When the flaps are down the outboard ailerons must be used because of a disrupted flow across the inboard ailerons.
When the spoilers are extended, the outboard ailerons must be used because of a disrupted flow across the inboard ailerons.
When the flaps are down, the outboard ailerons must be used to compensate for the decreased airspeed.
When the spoilers are deployed, the outboard ailerons must be used to compensate for the increased stability.

questions.query: The spoiler mixer combines the input from...

options.text: the speedbrake lever with the input from the aileron control wheel for roll control.
the aileron control wheel with the input from the flap lever for roll control.
the aileron control wheel with the input from the rudder pedals to prevent adverse yaw.
the speedbrake lever with the input from the landing gear lever for spoiling lift when on the ground.

questions.query: The hydraulic actuators of the trailing-edge flaps are...

options.text: rotary, multi piston-type actuators driving screw spindles.

questions.query: Which statement regarding ground and flight spoilers is true?

options.text: Ground spoilers have a larger deflection angle than flight spoilers.
Ground spoilers deflect symmetrically; flight spoilers deflect asymmetrically.
Ground spoilers decrease lift and increase drag; flight spoilers only increase drag.
Ground spoilers are speed brakes; flight spoilers are roll devices.

questions.query: To prevent flap blow-back during a hydraulic system failure, use is made of...

options.text: friction and mechanical locks in the (ball) nut to prevent the flap spindle (screw jack) from rotating.
the load-limit relief-system to reduce the aerodynamic load on the flaps.

questions.query: The flap/slat asymmetry protection system must detect a disagree between the...

options.text: left and right flap and/or slat position.
flap/slat lever and the actual flap/slat position.

questions.query: An auto slat system...

options.text: extends the slats during flap down selection.
retracts the slats when the airspeed becomes too high.
retracts the slats during a hydraulic system failure.

questions.query: What is the difference between a spoiler and a speed brake?

options.text: A spoiler decreases lift and increases drag; a speed brake only increases drag.
A spoiler improves aerodynamic performance; a speed brake degrades aerodynamic performance.
A spoiler is for use in flight; a speed brake is for use on ground.
A spoiler is attached to the fuselage; a speed brake is attached to the wing.

questions.query:
In a small aircraft with fixed landing gear and no hydraulic powerpack, the flaps are operated...

  1. mechanically;
  2. electrically;
  3. hydraulically;
  4. pneumatically.

The answer with most correct options is...

When extended, slats...

  1. create a slot;
  2. increase the camber of the wing;
  3. increase the wing surface area;
  4. increase the drag.

The answer with most correct options is...

When extended, Kruger flaps:

  1. create one or more slots;
  2. increase the camber of the wing;
  3. increase the wing surface area;
  4. increase the drag.

The answer with most correct options is...
A fly-by-wire system...

options.text: operates the flight controls through wires instead of cables.
controls the flight controls through rotary knobs on the glareshield panel.

questions.query: When a fly-by-wire system operates in 'direct law', the...

options.text: flight controls are controlled and operated through steel cables.
flight controls are electrically controlled and hydraulically operated.
flight controls are controlled through steel cables but are hydraulically operated.
aircraft is controlled through the secondary flight controls and asymmetric thrust.

questions.query:
A fly-by-wire system (FBW) makes use of flight computers that may use different 'control laws'.

What happens when there is a small, single computer failure?

options.text: The system reverts to the alternate law with a degraded protection level.
The system reverts to the direct law without any protection level.
The FBW system is off and all control is via the conventional flight control system.
The FBW system is off and all control is via the trim devices (pitch trim, aileron trim and rudder trim).

questions.query: What makes a fly-by-wire system irreversible?

options.text: There is no mechanical feedback towards the control column/wheel/pedals.
Once installed, the mechanical steel control cables are permanently removed.
The FBW system keeps the aircraft in its flight envelope.

questions.query: Cabin temperature in large aircraft is controlled by....

options.text: mixing cold LP bleed-air with hot HP bleed-air.
Modulating the airflow through the two heat-exchangers.
mixing air from the air cycle machine with air that bypasses the air cycle machine.

questions.query:
When the cabin temperature control valve opens, more air...

 

Note:
ACM = air cycle machine.

options.text: enters the ACM resulting in a lower cabin temperature.
bypasses the ACM resulting in a higher cabin temperature.
from the bleed-air system enters the cooling pack resulting in a higher cabin temperature.
bypasses the bleed-air pre-cooler resulting in a lower cabin temperature.

questions.query: In a piston engine aircraft, the air for the inflatable boots is taken from...

Before compressor bleed-air enters the fuselage it passes a...

  1. pre-cooler;
  2. pressure regulating and shut-off valve;
  3. flow control valve;
  4. dehumidifier;
  5. centrifugal breather;
  6. air filter.
In a turbine engine aircraft, the air for the cabin pressurisation system is taken from a...
During ground operation of a gasturbine engine in idle, the pneumatic system is...

options.text: supplied through the LP bleed valve of the HPC.
supplied through the HP bleed valve of the HPC.
supplied through the LP and HP bleed valves of the HPC.
not supplied as the LP and HP bleed valves are closed on the ground.

questions.query: The bleed-air pre-cooler is cooled by...

The bleed-air pressure-regulating and shut-off valve closes when there is a(n)...

  1. overpressure;
  2. overtemperature;
  3. duct leak;
  4. oil leak.
The bleed-airisolation valve separates the...

options.text: left bleed-air system from the right bleed-air system.
APU bleed-air system from the engine bleed-air system.

questions.query: The window defroster in small aircraft uses...

options.text: hot exhaust air sprayed on the outside of the windshield.
heated air from the engine compartment sprayed on the inner side of the windshield.
heated air from an engine driven compressor.
heated air from an electrical cabin heater.

questions.query: When the rpm of a gasturbine engine increases, the cabin pressure is kept the same because initially the...

options.text: temperature control valve moves towards a closed position.
bleed-air pressure-regulating and shut-off valve moves towards a closed position.
outflow valve moves towards a closed position.
flow control valve moves towards a closed position.

questions.query: During flight at a constant aircraft- and cabin altitude, the outflow valve is...

options.text: fully open to allow ventilation and to compensate for uncontrolled leaks.
partially open to compensate for the controlled and uncontrolled leaks.
partially open to maintain the cabin altitude and to allow ventilation.

questions.query: When the aircraft is taxiing towards the runway the cabin altitude is...
Which statement regarding the distribution of cabin air is correct?

options.text: Pack 1 supplies the flight compartment and the cargo compartment; pack 2 supplies the passenger compartment.
Only a small part of one pack supplies the flight compartment; the remaining part of this air is being mixed with air from the other pack in order to supply the passenger compartment.
Pack 1 supplies cold air; pack 2 supplies hot air which is mixed to obtain the selected temperature.
Fresh air is first delivered to the flight compartment and then recirculated into to the passenger compartment.

questions.query: An example of a de-icing system is [1] and of an anti-icing system is [2].
When is it most likely that ice broken loose from the engine air intake is ingested by that engine?

Anti-icing systems can be installed on the leading edges of the:

  1. nose;
  2. wings;
  3. horizontal stabiliser;
  4. vertical stabiliser;
  5. engine air intake
  6. outside air temperature sensor.

The alternative with most correct answers is...

Which of the following aircraft components are in general protected against ice accretion?

  1. leading edges of wings and stabilisers;
  2. probes of pitot tubes, angle of attack vanes and temperature sensors;
  3. windshields and side windows;
  4. air intakes of engine and APU.

 

The alternative with most correct answers is...

Which of these two statements about ice protection is true?

  1. Anti-icing of engine inlets is usually accomplished by conducting hot air through the leading edge of the engine nacelles.
  2. The air used for anti-icing is heated by thermostat-controlled electrical heaters.
Engine anti-icing...

options.text: is only applied on the front side, mainly the cowl leading edge.
is found throughout the length of the engine.
is not switched on before a small layer of ice has formed.

questions.query: What types of ice protection can be found at the air intake of turbofan engines?
The engine ice protection system that - in principle - cost no or very little extra fuel is...

options.text: propeller blade heating by electric heating elements.

questions.query: The rubber strips on the inner leading edge of the propeller blades are...
Regarding ice protection, hold-over time is the time between...

options.text: start de-icing fluid application and fluid failure.
start Type-I treatment and end Type-II treatment.
illumination of ice-detect light and selection of de-icing systems.

questions.query: The fluid that is sprayed on the outside of the windshield to prevent water to adhere is...
Side windows are often heated to...
Which statement is true regarding the rubber boots that cover the leading edges of wings and stabilisers?

options.text: The boots are filled with hot bleed-air that melt ice.
The boots are pressurised by liquid glycol.
The boots are electrically vibrated to prevent ice.
The boots are alternately inflated and deflated to break ice.

questions.query:
Which statement regarding step de-icing is true?

 

Note

Step de-cing consists of a first step with fluid type-I follewed by a second step with fluid type-2.

options.text: Step-1 is done with external ice protection systems; Step-2 with internal ice protection systems.
Step-1 is a de-icing procedure; Step-2 an anti-icing procedure.
Step-1 is done on the ground; Step-2 when airborne.
Step-1 is with brooms; Step-2 with hot unthickened liquid.

questions.query: When the ICE DETECT light comes on, the flight crew must...

options.text: leave icing conditions as soon as possible.
make a visual check first before activating the anti-icing systems.

questions.query: The operating principle of an ice detector may be based on...

options.text: the outside air temperature dropping below 0 C.

questions.query: When the ICING light comes on...

options.text: the flight crew should activate the heater of the ice detector.
the heater of the ice detector is automatically activated.

questions.query: The function of the fuel dump system is to transport fuel...

options.text: from one tank to another in case of an engine failure, a fuel- and/or flap asymmetry or a trim problem.
back into the fuel truck in case of a too high take-off mass.
into the engine exhaust for extra thrust during take-off at hot-and-high climates.
overboard in case of a too high landing mass.

questions.query: Fuel is normally stored in wing tanks that are located in the...

options.text: wing torsion box to unload the fuselage.
leading edge to bring the CG forward to prevent flutter.
trailing edge to bring the CG close to the NP.
tip to reduce tip vortices causd by induced drag.

questions.query: In the fuel system of a small single engine piston aircraft like a TB-10, there...

options.text: is an electric booster pump in each tank.
is a booster pump in each tank and a primer pump in the fuel line to the engine.

questions.query: The purpose of the collector tank (or feedbox) of the aircraft fuel system is to...

options.text: collect sediment at the bottom of the tank.
distribute fuel to the various tanks during refueling.
ventilate the tank during pressure refueling and defueling.
ensure sufficient fuel for the booster pumps regardless of manouvres.

questions.query: The correct procedure to solve a fuel asymmetry is...

options.text: use ailerons and aileron trim to maintain level flight.
bank the aircraft towards the low quantity tank while applying a small amount of opposite rudder.
reduce power of the engine that is supplied from the tank with the lowest quantity.
open the crossfeed valve and set the booster pumps of the low quantity tank to off.

questions.query: A fuel asymmetry is an unbalance between...

options.text: the wing tanks and the stabiliser tanks.
the inner wing tank (collector tank or feedbox) and the outer wing tank.

questions.query: Which statement regarding fuel for turbine engines is true?

options.text: In extreme cold atmospheres turbine engines use JET A-1.
JET A has a waxing point of -47 deg C.

questions.query: Static dischargers...

options.text: prevent the build-up of static electricity during taxiing.
can be found near the tips of wings and tail.
are not necessary when the structure is properly bonded.

questions.query:
What causes the conduction of electricity in a metal wire?

  1. Protons are attracted by the negative pole of a voltage source.
  2. Electrons are attracted by the positive pole of a voltage source.
The total resistance (Rt) of two resistors connected in parallel can be calculated by...

Which statement about electrical bonding is true?

 

Note

Be careful with the negations.

options.text: Electrical bonding is not possible in aircraft with a composite structure.
Electrical bonding does not increase the weight because electric return wires can be deleted.
Electrical bonding is a welding technique to connect metal parts together through heat.
An aircraft that is electrically bonded does not need static dischargers.

questions.query: A thermistor is a...
Capacitance of a capacitor is expressed as follows...

options.text: Xc = 1 / (2 x pi x f x C).

questions.query: Inductive reactance (XL) is...

options.text: 2 x x f x L.
( x I x N) / l.
d / d t.
( x A) / d.

questions.query: The resemblance (overeenkomst) between a relay and a solenoid is that they are both...

options.text: used to open the circuit in case of a too high current.

questions.query: The purpose of the guard cap over a switch is...

options.text: to prevent the ingress of dust and moisture.

questions.query: Contrary to a micro-switch, a proximity-sensor...

options.text: is used to detect more than two positions.

questions.query: A proximity-sensor is a...

options.text: logic-gate that converts two or more inputs into one single output.
position sensor to detect the angular position of flight controls.
touch-screen sensor used in modern display systems.
position sensor to detect the discrete position of landing gear, flight controls and doors.

questions.query: Electrical bonding is...

options.text: creating a closed electrical circuit by interconnecting the positive and negative poles.
welding metals together by applying heat caused by large electric currents.
installing return wires from all electric components back to the battery and/or generator.
using the metal structure of the aircraft as a common electric ground.

questions.query: Electrical bonding is the installation of...

options.text: static wicks at the tips of wings and empennage.
static dischargers at the ailerons, elevators and rudder.
switches, relays and solenoids that can close electrical circuits.
metal cables between metallic aircraft parts to create a common electrical reference pole.

questions.query:
Real power in an AC electrical system is expressed in...

 

Note: In the future there will be no EASA LO for this question.
Which statement about the connections of a transistor is true?

options.text: A transistor has two connections: anode and cathode.
A transistor has two connections: collector and emitter.
A transistor has three connections: positive (+), negative (-) and neutral (0).
A transistor has three connections: base, collector and emitter.

questions.query: Which bridge-rectifier correctly shows a single-phase, full-wave rectifier?
A primary, chemical cell is...

options.text: a cell that is used to charge a secondary cell.
the anode part of a chemical cell.
a battery consisting of two lead electrodes and an acid electrolyte.

questions.query: The capacity of batteries is expressed in...

a thin, removable transparent plastic film that is attached to the outside of the windshield.
an electrically heated outer pane of the windshield.
bleed-air that is sprayed onto the windshields from the outside.

questions.query: Quick donning masks refer to oxygen masks...

options.text: in smoke hoods that allow crew to move through the cabin.
that automatically drop down in case of a decompression.
that can be put on using one hand and ready for use.
used for medical purposes in case of sick pasengers.

questions.query: Which statement regarding the flight crew oxygen mask is correct?

options.text: Above a certain cabin altitude the mask will automatically enter the 'EMERGENCY' mode.
In the 'NORMAL' mode, a short burst of oxygen is released at a rate depending on cabin altitude.
In the 'NORMAL' mode diluted oxygen will be supplied only when inhaled.
In the '100%' mode, oxygen will be supplied at a constant flow.

questions.query: Oxygen masks will be automatically presented in the passenger cabin when the...
The primer (or booster) pump in the fuel system of a small aircraft is used...

options.text: to supply the engine with fuel when the engine-driven pump is off.
to circulate fuel in the tank to prevent waxing and stratification.

questions.query: Fuel is preferably stored in the wings because this is the most...

options.text: distant location with regard to passenger safety.
practical location for gravity feed of the engines.
ideal location to unload the wing root.
best location to heat and ventilate the fuel.

questions.query: Dural is...

options.text: a composite material with a duration that lasts for many years.

questions.query: A construction member that maintains its strength, even when a crack has occured, is called...
The difference between the Type-I and Type-II ice protection fluids is...

options.text: Type-1 is a liquid; Type-II is solid.
Type-1 is for anti-icing; Type-II is for de-icing.
Type-1 is sprayed on hot; Type-II is sprayed on cold.

questions.query: How is redundancy achieved in the hydraulic system of a large aircraft?

options.text: Installing multiple systems with alternate pressure sources.
Designing a simple, single system with mechanical backups.
Ability to pressusrise the system with a hand pump on the flight deck.
pressurising the system with bleed-air in the event of a hydraulic leak.

questions.query: If the landing gear operating speed must be controlled to counteract the effects of gravity and/or aerodynamic loads, the hydraulic system uses the following valves
Nose-wheel shimmy occurs when

options.text: there is combination of lateral imbalance and play during taxiing.
the nosewheel is deflected during touch down.
the speed of the nosewheel is lower than the groundspeed.

questions.query: What is tyre creep?

options.text: A tyre that has slipped on the rim.
A tyre that is reduced in size due to wear.
A tyre that suffers from tread separation.
A tyre that is damaged by cuts and flat spots.

questions.query: State the method of supplying air for the pneumatic systems for piston engine aircraft:

  1. engines,
  2. APU,
  3. ram-air,
  4. HP ground supply unit,
  5. LP ground supply unit.

Complete the following two statements.

  1. Nose wheel shimmy is a condition where the nose wheel undergoes an oscillation in the (1) plane.
  2. To minimise the effects, a shimmy damper is installed between (2).

options.text:
1. horizontal and vertical plane.
  2. the piston and the cylinder of the oleo strut.

1. vertical plane.
  2. the piston and the cylinder of the oleo strut.

questions.query: Brake discs are made of...

State the advantages of a Fly-By-Wire system in comparison with a conventional flight control system:  

  1. Improved aircraft handling;
  2. Rapid and accurate responses to pilot input;
  3. Fuel saving;
  4. Reduced weight;
  5. Artificial feel;
  6. Full functioning primary controls in the event of complete system failure;
  7. Reduced maintenance costs due to less mechanical components.

Which additives are found in Jet-A1?

Hydraulic systems transmit power by moving (1) from one place to another, the systems obey (2) Law and pressure in aircraft is usually measured in (3).
Why do windshields consist of more layers than side windows?

options.text: To take up the differential pressure load.

questions.query: A cargofire extinguishing system uses
Explain the need for a 'feel system' in a fully powered flight control system.

options.text: A feel system provides valuable force feedback to the pilot.
A feel system provides aircraft the ability to manoeuvre with proportional output to input.
A feel system prevents flight envelope excursions.
A feel system ensures the pilot receives the full force of the aerodynamic pressures received by the control surfaces.

questions.query:
Which of the following protections does the fly-by-wire system offer in the 'normal law'? 

  1. Load factor protection,
  2. Stall protection,
  3. High speed protection,
  4. Pitch attitude protection,
  5. Bank angle protection,
  6. Negative-g protection.
When is an engine overheat alert activated in a system with two fire wires?

options.text: When an overheat is detected by one detector loop.
When an overheat is detected by both detector loops.
When an overheat is detected by one detector loop for more than 30 seconds.
When an overheat is detected by both detector loops within a period of 30 seconds.

questions.query: The air supplied to a diluter demand oxygen system is taken from ...
In the context of airframe load path philosophies a fail safe component is...

options.text: a component that has a design fatigue life such that the probability of failure in that life is assessed as remote.
a component that does not affect the structural strength of the aircraft.
a component with a safe life, which means it will not fail in its stated life.
a component, which is designed so that, following its failure, other components can withstand reasonable loads without failure.

questions.query: The state in which the breathing oxygen for the crew oxygen mask is usually stored is
Which of the following statements regarding carbon disc brakes is correct?

options.text: Carbon brakes wear more slowly than steel brakes at low braking pressures.
Carbon brakes have a higher friction coefficient than steel brakes.
Carbon brakes have a higher weight than steel brakes.
Carbon brakes use a single disc; steel brakes use multiple-discs.

  1. rudder-pedal linkages,

  1. The elevators of large, modern aircraft are actuated (1);
  2. Their horizontal stabiliser is actuated (2).

options.text: bleed hot air for the pneumatic system.
bleed hot air to prevent an engine overheat.
inject hot air to prevent ice-crystal icing.
